result.markdown:
--- title: "Week 9: Factors &
Pull Requests" subtitle: "Miscellany" author: "Joe Nese" institute: "University of Oregon
Fall 2024" format: revealjs: theme: default highlight-style: github incremental: false fig-width: 9 fig-height: 3.5 scrollable: true multiplex: true execute: echo: true warning: false embed-resources: true --- ![](./images/student-experience-surveys-slide.png) # Factors & Pull Requests Week 9 ## Agenda {.smaller} * Final Project Review * Discuss factors and factor re-leveling * Walk through a [pull request (PR)]{style='color:#009E73'} * ~~AMA~~ *next week instead* **Overall Purpose** * Understand factors and how to manipulate them * Understand how to complete a [pull request (PR)]{style='color:#009E73'} ## Homework Review Homework 9 ## Your code! ![](https://media2.giphy.com/media/8X6UFXpJFndo4/giphy.gif?cid=ecf05e47ov2j4bec7wwcp7el1ob0b0oe7towmyta3ml46kvz&rid=giphy.gif&ct=g) # Final Project ## Final Project - Data Prep Script * Expected to be a work in progress * Provided to your peers so they can learn from you as much as you can learn from their feedback **Peer Review** * Understand the purpose of the exercise * Conducted as a professional product * Should be **very** encouraging * Zero tolerance policy for inappropriate comments ## Final Project – Presentation * Groups are expected to present for about **15-20 minutes** (split evenly among members). Group order randomly assigned. * Email me your presentation by midnight 12/3 so I can share through my machine. ## Final Project – Presentation Presentation cover the following: * Share your journey (everyone, at least for a minute or two) * Discuss challenges you had along the way * Celebrate your successes * Discuss challenges you are still facing * Discuss substantive findings * Show off your cool figures! * Discuss next `R` hurdle you want to address ## Final Project – Paper {.smaller} * Quarto document + Abstract, Intro, Methods, Results, Discussion, References + Should be brief: 3,500 words max * No code displayed - should look similar to a manuscript being submitted for publication * Include at least 1 table * Include at least 2 plots * Should be fully open, reproducible, and housed on GitHub + I should be able to clone your repository, open the R Studio Project, and reproduce the full manuscript (by rendering the quarto doc) ## Final Project The following functions: * `pivot_longer()` * `mutate()` * `select()` * `filter()` * `pivot_wider()` * `group_by()` * `summarize()` ## Scoring Rubric Check the [syllabus](https://jnese.github.io/intro-DS-R_fall-2024/syllabus.html) for [Presentation](https://jnese.github.io/intro-DS-R_fall-2024/syllabus.html#final-project-presentation-25-points) and [Final Paper](https://jnese.github.io/intro-DS-R_fall-2024/syllabus.html#final-paper-110) scoring rubrics # Factors just the basics ## When do we really want factors? Generally two reasons to declare a factor 1. Only finite number of categories + treatment/control + income categories + performance levels + etc. 2. Use in modeling ## Creating factors {.smaller} Imagine you have a vector of months ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} months_4 <- c("Dec", "Apr", "Jan", "Mar") ``` ::: . . . We could store this as a string, but there are issues with this: * There are only 12 possible months + factors will help us weed out values that don't conform to our predefined levels, which helps safeguard against typos, etc. * You can't sort this vector in a meaningful way + default is alphabetic sorting . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sort(months_4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Apr" "Dec" "Jan" "Mar" ``` ::: ::: ## Define it as a factor ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} months_4 <- factor(months_4, levels = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Jul", "Aug", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec")) months_4 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Dec Apr Jan Mar Levels: Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Oct Nov Dec ``` ::: ::: . . . Now we can sort ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sort(months_4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Jan Mar Apr Dec Levels: Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Oct Nov Dec ``` ::: ::: ## Accessing and modifying levels {.smaller} Use the `levels()` function . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} levels(months_4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Jan" "Feb" "Mar" "Apr" "May" "Jun" "Jul" "Aug" "Sep" "Oct" "Nov" "Dec" ``` ::: ::: ## Provides an error check of sorts ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} months_4[5] <- "Jam" ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning in `[<-.factor`(`*tmp*`, 5, value = "Jam"): invalid factor level, NA generated ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} months_4 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Dec Apr Jan Mar Levels: Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Oct Nov Dec ``` ::: ::: ## What if we don’t specify levels? If you define a factor without specifying the levels, it will assign them alphabetically ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mnths <- factor(c("Dec", "Apr", "Jan", "Mar")) ``` ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Dec Apr Jan Mar Levels: Apr Dec Jan Mar ``` ::: ::: ## [`{forcats}`](https://forcats.tidyverse.org/) ![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tidyverse/forcats/master/man/figures/logo.png){width="10%"} * When working with factors, we can use the `{forcats}` package + `for cat`egorical variables + anagram of factors . . . * Part of the `{tidyverse}` so should be good to go . . . * All functions start with `fct_` + use the autofill in RStudio ## Change level order – `fct_inorder()` By the order in which they first appear ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} (mnths <- factor(c("Dec", "Apr", "Jan", "Mar"))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Dec Apr Jan Mar Levels: Apr Dec Jan Mar ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mnths %>% factor(., levels = c("Jan", "Mar", "Apr", "Dec")) %>% sort(.) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Jan Mar Apr Dec Levels: Jan Mar Apr Dec ``` ::: ::: ## Change level order – `fct_inorder()` By the order in which they first appear ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} (mnths <- factor(c("Dec", "Apr", "Jan", "Mar"))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Dec Apr Jan Mar Levels: Apr Dec Jan Mar ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} mnths %>% factor(., levels = c("Jan", "Mar", "Apr", "Dec")) %>% fct_inorder() %>% sort(.) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Dec Apr Jan Mar Levels: Dec Apr Jan Mar ``` ::: ::: ## Change level order – `fct_infreq()` By number of observations with each level (largest first) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2"} c("b", "b", "c", "a", "a", "a") %>% fct_infreq() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] b b c a a a Levels: a b c ``` ::: ::: . . . This can be **especially** useful for plotting ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(aes(x, fct_infreq(y)) ``` ::: ## Investigate factors * `{tidyverse}` gives you convenient way to evaluate factors + `count()` + `geom_bar()` or `geom_col())` with `{ggplot2}` * But don't forget about the base function `unique()` + e.g., `unique(df$factor_variable)` ## General Social Survey (GSS) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} forcats::gss_cat ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 21,483 × 9 year marital age race rincome partyid relig denom tvhours 1 2000 Never married 26 White $8000 to 9999 Ind,near … Prot… Sout… 12 2 2000 Divorced 48 White $8000 to 9999 Not str r… Prot… Bapt… NA 3 2000 Widowed 67 White Not applicable Independe… Prot… No d… 2 4 2000 Never married 39 White Not applicable Ind,near … Orth… Not … 4 5 2000 Divorced 25 White Not applicable Not str d… None Not … 1 6 2000 Married 25 White $20000 - 24999 Strong de… Prot… Sout… NA 7 2000 Never married 36 White $25000 or more Not str r… Chri… Not … 3 8 2000 Divorced 44 White $7000 to 7999 Ind,near … Prot… Luth… NA 9 2000 Married 44 White $25000 or more Not str d… Prot… Other 0 10 2000 Married 47 White $25000 or more Strong re… Prot… Sout… 3 # ℹ 21,473 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} gss_cat %>% count(partyid) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 10 × 2 partyid n 1 No answer 154 2 Don't know 1 3 Other party 393 4 Strong republican 2314 5 Not str republican 3032 6 Ind,near rep 1791 7 Independent 4119 8 Ind,near dem 2499 9 Not str democrat 3690 10 Strong democrat 3490 ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} levels(gss_cat$partyid) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "No answer" "Don't know" "Other party" [4] "Strong republican" "Not str republican" "Ind,near rep" [7] "Independent" "Ind,near dem" "Not str democrat" [10] "Strong democrat" ``` ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} unique(gss_cat$partyid) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Ind,near rep Not str republican Independent Not str democrat [5] Strong democrat Ind,near dem Strong republican Other party [9] No answer Don't know 10 Levels: No answer Don't know Other party ... Strong democrat ``` ::: ::: . . . How many `unique` categories are there (if you have a lot)? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} length(unique(gss_cat$partyid)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 10 ``` ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(gss_cat, aes(partyid)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(gss_cat, aes(fct_infreq(partyid))) + geom_bar() ``` ::: ggplot(gss_cat, aes([fct_infreq(]{style='color:#CC79A7'}partyid[)]{style='color:#CC79A7'})) + geom_bar() . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Change level order – `fct_relevel()` Change level order by hand, or move any number of levels to any location + *probably one I use most* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fct_relevel(variable_name, "first_level", "second_level", "third_level", ...) ``` :::
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fct_relevel(variable_name, "fourth_level", after = 3) ``` ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|2|3|4"} set.seed(3000) tibble( month = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec"), suspensions = sample(c(5:75), size = 10) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 10 × 2 month suspensions 1 Jan 19 2 Feb 51 3 Mar 61 4 Apr 14 5 May 25 6 Jun 27 7 Sep 15 8 Oct 21 9 Nov 7 10 Dec 59 ``` ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|6,7"} set.seed(3000) tibble( month = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec"), suspensions = sample(c(5:75), size = 10) ) %>% ggplot(aes(month, suspensions)) + geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|6|7"} set.seed(3000) tibble( month = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec"), suspensions = sample(c(5:75), size = 10) ) %>% mutate(month = fct_relevel(month, "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec", "Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May")) ``` ::: ## ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|8,9"} set.seed(3000) tibble( month = c("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec"), suspensions = sample(c(5:75), size = 10) ) %>% mutate(month = fct_relevel(month, "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec", "Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May")) %>% ggplot(aes(month, suspensions)) + geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Change level order – `fct_reorder()` Reorder according to another variable ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} (relig_summary <- gss_cat %>% group_by(relig) %>% summarise(tvhours = mean(tvhours, na.rm = TRUE), n = n())) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 15 × 3 relig tvhours n 1 No answer 2.72 93 2 Don't know 4.62 15 3 Inter-nondenominational 2.87 109 4 Native american 3.46 23 5 Christian 2.79 689 6 Orthodox-christian 2.42 95 7 Moslem/islam 2.44 104 8 Other eastern 1.67 32 9 Hinduism 1.89 71 10 Buddhism 2.38 147 11 Other 2.73 224 12 None 2.71 3523 13 Jewish 2.52 388 14 Catholic 2.96 5124 15 Protestant 3.15 10846 ``` ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(relig_summary, aes(tvhours, relig)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(relig_summary, aes(tvhours, fct_reorder(relig, tvhours))) + geom_point() ``` ::: ggplot(relig_summary, aes(tvhours, [fct_reorder(]{style='color:#CC79A7'}relig, [tvhours)]{style='color:#CC79A7'})) + geom_point() . . . ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-33-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Or `mutate()` the factor reorder ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2"} relig_summary %>% mutate(relig = fct_reorder(relig, tvhours)) %>% ggplot(aes(tvhours, relig)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Quick aside for error bars ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3|4,5|6"} (relig_summary_eb <- gss_cat %>% group_by(relig) %>% summarise(tvhours_mean = mean(tvhours, na.rm = TRUE), tvhours_se = sqrt(var(tvhours, na.rm = TRUE) / length(na.omit(tvhours))), n = n())) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 15 × 4 relig tvhours_mean tvhours_se n 1 No answer 2.72 0.326 93 2 Don't know 4.62 3.01 15 3 Inter-nondenominational 2.87 0.363 109 4 Native american 3.46 1.13 23 5 Christian 2.79 0.126 689 6 Orthodox-christian 2.42 0.355 95 7 Moslem/islam 2.44 0.269 104 8 Other eastern 1.67 0.449 32 9 Hinduism 1.89 0.197 71 10 Buddhism 2.38 0.235 147 11 Other 2.73 0.203 224 12 None 2.71 0.0590 3523 13 Jewish 2.52 0.151 388 14 Catholic 2.96 0.0453 5124 15 Protestant 3.15 0.0360 10846 ``` ::: ::: ## Quick aside for error bars ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1|2|3,4,5|6"} ggplot(relig_summary_eb, aes(tvhours_mean, fct_reorder(relig, tvhours_mean))) + geom_errorbarh(aes(xmin = tvhours_mean - 1.96 * tvhours_se, xmax = tvhours_mean + 1.96 * tvhours_se), color = "cornflowerblue") + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-36-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Modifying factor levels – `fct_recode()` Make modifying factors more explicit `fct_recode(var_name, "new level" = "old level"...` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2,3,4,5,6,7"} gss_cat %>% mutate(partyid = fct_recode(partyid, "Republican, strong" = "Strong republican", "Republican, weak" = "Not str republican", "Independent, near rep" = "Ind, near rep", "Independent, near dem" = "Ind, near dem", "Democrat, weak" = "Not str democrat", "Democrat, strong" = "Strong democrat")) %>% count(partyid) ``` ::: ## Collapsing levels – `fct_recode()` {.smaller} `fct_recode()` can also be used to collapse levels easily ::: {.cell output-location='fragment'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|9,10,11"} gss_cat %>% mutate(partyid = fct_recode(partyid, "Republican, strong" = "Strong republican", "Republican, weak" = "Not str republican", "Independent, near rep" = "Ind,near rep", "Independent, near dem" = "Ind,near dem", "Democrat, weak" = "Not str democrat", "Democrat, strong" = "Strong democrat", "Other" = "No answer", "Other" = "Don't know", "Other" = "Other party")) %>% count(partyid) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 8 × 2 partyid n 1 Other 548 2 Republican, strong 2314 3 Republican, weak 3032 4 Independent, near rep 1791 5 Independent 4119 6 Independent, near dem 2499 7 Democrat, weak 3690 8 Democrat, strong 3490 ``` ::: ::: ## Collapsing levels – `fct_collapse()` {.smaller} `fct_collapse()` is one of the more useful functions in `{forcats}` * Collapse all categories into Republican, Democrat, Independent, or Other ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2"} gss_cat %>% mutate(partyid = fct_collapse(partyid, Other = c("No answer", "Don't know", "Other party"), Rep = c("Strong republican", "Not str republican"), Ind = c("Ind,near rep", "Independent", "Ind,near dem"), Dem = c("Not str democrat", "Strong democrat") )) %>% count(partyid) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 × 2 partyid n 1 Other 548 2 Rep 5346 3 Ind 8409 4 Dem 7180 ``` ::: ::: ## Collapsing levels – `fct_lump_?()` `fct_lump_?()` – "lump" a bunch of categories together `fct_lump_n(factor_variable, n)` : lumps all levels except for the `n` most frequent (or least frequent if `n` < 0) into "Other" level . . . `fct_lump_min(factor_variable, min)` : lumps levels that appear fewer than `min` times . . . `fct_lump_prop(factor_variable, prop)` : lumps levels that appear in fewer `prop` $\times$ `n` times ## Collapsing levels – `fct_lump_n()` Collapse to `n = 9` religious groups: top 8 groups plus "Other" ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2"} gss_cat %>% mutate(rel = fct_lump_n(relig, 9)) %>% count(rel) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 9 × 2 rel n 1 Inter-nondenominational 109 2 Christian 689 3 Moslem/islam 104 4 Buddhism 147 5 None 3523 6 Jewish 388 7 Catholic 5124 8 Protestant 10846 9 Other 553 ``` ::: ::: ## Collapsing levels – `fct_lump_min()` Collapse to all religious groups that appear less than `min = 200` into "Other" ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2"} gss_cat %>% mutate(rel = fct_lump_min(relig, min = 200)) %>% count(rel) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 2 rel n 1 Christian 689 2 None 3523 3 Jewish 388 4 Catholic 5124 5 Protestant 10846 6 Other 913 ``` ::: ::: ## Collapsing levels – `fct_lump_prop()` Collapse to all religious groups that appear less than `prop = 10%` into "Other" ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|2"} gss_cat %>% mutate(rel = fct_lump_prop(relig, prop = .10)) %>% count(rel) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 × 2 rel n 1 None 3523 2 Catholic 5124 3 Protestant 10846 4 Other 1990 ``` ::: ::: ## Missing levels {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} levels(gss_cat$race) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Other" "Black" "White" "Not applicable" ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} gss_cat %>% count(race) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 race n 1 Other 1959 2 Black 3129 3 White 16395 ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} table(gss_cat$race) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Other Black White Not applicable 1959 3129 16395 0 ``` ::: ::: ## Missing levels ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(gss_cat, aes(race)) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-46-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Missing levels ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3"} ggplot(gss_cat, aes(race)) + geom_bar() + scale_x_discrete(drop = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](w9_factors_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-47-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Review `fct_inorder()` : By the order in which they first appear . . . `fct_infreq()` : By number of observations with each level (largest first) . . . `fct_relevel()` : Change level order by hand, or move any number of levels to any location . . . `fct_reorder()` : Change level order according to another variable . . . `fct_recode()` : Recode levels into new named levels . . . `fct_collapse()` : Collapse many levels into fewer levels . . . `fct_lump_?()` : Recode all levels into "*Other*": * except for the `n` most frequent - `fct_lump_n()` * that appear fewer than `min` times - `fct_lump_min()` * that appear less than `prop`% - `fct_lump_prop()` # Revisiting git ## Let's revisit git Talk with neighbor. What do these terms mean? Talk about them in the order you would encounter them in your workflow * [clone]{style='color:#009E73'} * [pull]{style='color:#009E73'} * [stage]{style='color:#009E73'} * [commit]{style='color:#009E73'} * [push]{style='color:#009E73'} * [repo]{style='color:#009E73'} * [remote]{style='color:#009E73'} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
03:00
``` ::: ::: # Pull Requests ## Peer Review of Data Prep Script {.smaller} Expectations Feedback: 1. Note at least three areas of strength 2. Note at least one thing you learned from reviewing their script 3. Note at least one and no more than three areas for improvement . . . Making your code publicly available can feel daunting * The purpose of this portion of the final project is to help us all learn from each other * We are all learning + Be constructive in your feedback + Be kind * Under no circumstances will negative comments be tolerated + Any comments that could be perceived as negative, and outside the scope of the code, will result in an immediate score of zero ## Peer Review GitHub Process {.smaller} 1. Locate GitHub [repo]{style='color:#009E73'} of assigned peer to review 2. Fork the [repo]{style='color:#009E73'} 3. Clone the [repo]{style='color:#009E73'} 4. Provide script feedback + edit the .qmd file directly + edit code + provide comments in code and/or text (`Ctrl/Command + Shift + C`) 5. [commit]{style='color:#009E73'} & [push]{style='color:#009E73'}! 6. Create [Pull Request (PR)]{style='color:#009E73'} * Write brief summary of the PR that includes + \>= 3 strengths + \>= 1 thing you learned + 1 to 3 three areas of improvement ## 1. Locate GitHub repo of assigned peer to review {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Student Repo to Review File to Review

````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ## 2. Fork the repo 1. Navigate to the (host) GitHub repo 2. Click Fork in the upper right corner 3. Owner? – **your GitHub account** ![](./images/gh_fork.png) ## 3. Clone the repo (@) Clone the repo copy the URL ![](./images/gh_clone.png) ## 3. Clone the repo (@) Open GitKraken *Clone with URL* Where will it live on your local machine? It's own folder, with no other RProjects ![](./images/gh_clone2.png) ## 4. Provide script feedback {.smaller} * Open `RProj` in your [local]{style='color:#009E73'} (i.e., on your machine) * Find the .qmd document you will be reviewing + it should be a .qmd document * Make your edits/comments + edit code as you like + include a comment for each edit! + Provide comments in code **and/or** text (`Ctrl/Command + Shift + C`) * Commit as you go (if you are working on this across sessions/days) * [Push]{style='color:#009E73'} **only when you are finished** ## 5. [commit]{style='color:#009E73'} & [push]{style='color:#009E73'} Once you have provided comments and code suggestions to the script - save the changes - go to GitKraken - [commit]{style='color:#009E73'} - [push]{style='color:#009E73'} ## 5. Create Pull Request (PR) {.smaller} (1) Navigate back to the (host) GitHub repo . . . (2) Click “Pull requests” ![](./images/gh_pr.png) . . . (3) Click “New pull request” ![](./images/gh_newpr.png) ## 6. Create Pull Request (PR) {.smaller} (4) Click *"Compare across forks"* ![](./images/gh_compareforks.png) . . . Use drop-downs so that: * **left** = *host* repo * **right** = *your* repo ![](./images/gh_compareforks2.png) . . . You will be able view the changes you made to the .qmd document ## 6. Create Pull Request (PR) (5) Click *"Create pull request"* ![](./images/gh_comparechanges.png) ## 6. Create Pull Request (PR) {.smaller} Write a brief summary list of the PR that includes * \>= 3 strengths * \>= 1 thing you learned * 1 to 3 three areas of improvement * **Use markdown formatting, headers or list!** ![](./images/gh_writereview.png) ## 6. Create Pull Request (PR) (6) Click *"Create pull request"* when you're done ![](./images/gh_comparechanges.png) ## 6. Create Pull Request (PR) {.smaller} Recap (1) Navigate back to the (host) GitHub repo (2) Click *"Pull requests"* (3) Click *"New pull request"* (4) Click *"Compare across forks"* * Use drop-downs so that: + Host [repo]{style='color:#009E73'} is on the left, your [repo]{style='color:#009E73'} is on the right * View changes! (5) Click *"Create pull request"* * Write brief summary list of the [PR]{style='color:#009E73'} that includes + \>= 3 strengths + \>= 1 thing you learned + 1 to 3 three areas of improvement + **Use markdown formatting, headers, or list!** (6) Click *"Create pull request"* ## Reviewing your PRs You will get an email from GitHub 1. Click on first link, for [PR]{style='color:#009E73'} 2. Click *"Commits"* tab 3. Click on *"File changes"* to see changes 4. Copy/paste all desired changes 5. Don’t close *"Close PR"* just yet; I want to review # Next time ## Before next class * Final Project + [Final Project: Peer Review of Script]{style='color:#FF0000'} + [Final Project: Presentations]{style='color:#FF0000'} - email me your content before class * Homework + **Homework 10** * AMA
